text.b: VCU VIRGINIA TREATMENT CENTER FOR CHILDREN

page.text: Ramey Kemp & Associates, Inc. (RKA) has performed this Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) for
the proposed Virginia Treatment Center for Children (VTCC) located in the northwest
quadrant of US 1 (Brook Road) at Sherwood Avenue in Richmond, Virginia. The purpose of
this study is to determine the potential impacts on the surrounding transportation system
created by traffic generated by the proposed facility, and recommend improvements needed to
mitigate the impacts. The study analyzes existing (2013), no-build (2015), and build (2015)
traffic conditions during the weekday AM and PM peak hours.
The proposed 32-bed facility will be located on the north side of Sherwood Avenue between I-
95 and the existing hospital. Figure 1 shows the site location map. The scope of this study
was developed based on discussion with the City of Richmond and is outlined in the
Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), which is in the Appendix.
The following intersections are included in the study area:
 Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard
The property is currently vacant, and is zoned R-3. The surrounding land uses are industrial to
the west, institutional to the south and east, and residential to the north.

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

text.b: 1.3. Proposed Land Use and Site Access

page.text: The proposed 32-bed facility is expected to employ 120 people, and is anticipated to be fully
built out in 2015. The proposed access consists of connecting to the surface parking lot that
serves the existing hospital, which will provide access to the existing driveways on Brook
Road and Sherwood Avenue. No new driveways are proposed with this facility.
The study area for this TIA consists of three roadways – US 1 (Brook Road), Sherwood
Avenue, and Brookland Park Boulevard. Brook Road is a four-lane median divided arterial
with an average daily traffic (ADT) volume of 11,000 vehicles per day, and a posted speed
limit of 35 miles per hour (mph) in the vicinity of the site.
On-street parking is permitted along portions of Brook Road and there are two bus stops along
the property frontage provided by the Greater Richmond Transit Company (GRTC):
 Northwest corner of Brook Road at Sherwood Avenue
 Southeast corner of Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard

text.b: Looking north on Brook Road at Site Driveway

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: Sherwood Avenue is a two-lane roadway with an ADT volume of 3,000 vehicles per day, and
a posted speed limit of 25 mph in the vicinity of the site.
Brookland Park Boulevard is a four-lane median divided roadway with an ADT volume of
9,000 vehicles per day, and a posted speed limit of 35 mph in the vicinity of the site. Figure 2

text.b: Looking west on Sherwood Avenue at the Main Driveway

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: The traffic capacity analysis was performed with Synchro 8, which is a comprehensive
software package that allows the user to determine the level-of-service (LOS) for the study
intersections based on the control delay thresholds specified in the 2010 Highway Capacity
Manual (HCM). LOS is a qualitative measure of traffic operation that ranges from LOS A,
which represents free-flow conditions, to LOS F, which represents congestion and long delays.
For signalized intersections, Synchro calculates the average control delay and queue length for
each lane group, and the LOS for the overall intersection. For unsignalized intersections,
Synchro calculates the average control delay and queue length for stop-controlled movements,
but does not provide an overall LOS for the intersection. Table 1 shows the control delay
thresholds for unsignalized and signalized movements.

text.b: Highway Capacity Manual – Levels-of-Service and Delay

page.text: LOS D is typically an acceptable overall LOS for signalized intersections, and it is common
for left-turn and minor street movements to experience LOS E or F at both signalized and

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: Existing lane configurations, lane widths, storage capacities, traffic signal timing and other
intersection and roadway information was collected in the field by RKA. Weekday AM peak
hour (7:00 – 9:00 AM) and PM peak hour (4:00 – 6:00 PM) turning movement traffic counts
were conducted by RKA during the weeks of September 30 and October 7, 2013 at the
 Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard (Signalized)
Traffic volumes were balanced between intersections where appropriate. Figure 3 shows the
existing (2013) weekday AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes, and the traffic count data are

text.b: 3.2. Analysis of Existing (2013) Peak Hour Traffic Conditions

page.text: The existing (2013) weekday AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes at the study intersections
were analyzed to determine the current levels-of-service under existing traffic conditions.

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: In order to account for growth of traffic and subsequent traffic conditions at a future year,
background traffic projections are needed. Background traffic is the component of traffic due
to the growth of the community and surrounding area that is anticipated to occur regardless of
whether or not the proposed development is constructed.
The following is a summary of the average daily traffic (ADT) volume data published by
VDOT for Brook Road in the vicinity of the site:
To be conservative, an annual growth rate of 3% was applied to the peak hour traffic volumes
at the study intersections. Figure 4 shows the no-build 2015 AM and PM peak hours traffic
Based on discussion with the City of Richmond, there are no approved developments that will
have an impact on the study area.

page.text: The existing hospital is a 47-bed facility with 250 employees. Table 2 is a comparison of the
trip generation estimates for the existing facility based on the Institute of Transportation

text.i: th

page.text: Edition, and the actual AM and PM peak hour
traffic counts at the existing driveways.

text.i: ITE Equation

page.text: In this case, the ITE trip generation equation based on the number of employees matches the
actual trip generation of the site closely. Table 3 shows the ITE trip generation calculations
for the proposed facility based on the number of employees and the number of beds. To be
conservative and consistent with the trip generation of the existing facility, the trip generation
potential of the new facility is based on the top line of Table 3.

VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: The site trip distribution for the proposed facility was determined based on the existing traffic
patterns, the surrounding roadway network, and engineering judgment:
 40% to / from the west on Sherwood Avenue
 20% to / from the north on Brook Road
 20% to / from the south on Brook Road
 15% to / from the west on Brookland Park Boulevard
 5% to / from the east on Brookland Park Boulevard
Figure 5 shows the site trip distribution, and Figure 6 shows the site trip assignment at the

page.text: In order to estimate traffic conditions with the site fully developed, the site trips (Figure 6)
were added to the no-build (2015) traffic volumes (Figure 4) to determine build (2015) traffic
conditions. Figure 7 shows the build (2015) peak hour traffic volumes with the proposed site

text.b: Analysis of Build (2015) Peak Hour Traffic

page.text: Study intersections were analyzed with the build (2015) traffic volumes using the same
methodology previously discussed for existing and no-build traffic conditions. The analysis
results are presented in Section 8 of this report.

text.b: 8.1. Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard

page.text: The signalized intersection of Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard was analyzed under
existing (2013), no-build (2015) and build (2015) traffic conditions. Table 4 is a summary of
the analysis results, and the Synchro output is included in the Appendix.

text.b: Analysis Summary of Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard

page.text: Capacity analysis indicates that this signalized intersection currently operates at LOS C during
the AM and PM peak hours. Under future no-build and build conditions, the overall
intersection is expected to continue to operate at LOS C during the AM and PM peak hours,
with all movements operating at LOS E or better.

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: The signalized intersection of Brook Road at Sherwood Avenue was analyzed under existing
(2013), no-build (2015) and build (2015) traffic conditions. Table 5 is a summary of the
analysis results, and the Synchro output is included in the Appendix.

text.b: Analysis Summary of Brook Road at Sherwood Avenue

page.text: Capacity analysis indicates that this signalized intersection currently operates at LOS A during
both the AM and PM peak hours. Under future no-build and build conditions, the overall
intersection is expected to operate at LOS A during the AM peak hour and at LOS B during
the PM peak hour, with all movements operating at LOS D or better.

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: The unsignalized intersection of Brook Road at the Site Driveway was analyzed under existing
(2013), no-build (2015) and build (2015) traffic conditions. Table 6 is a summary of the
analysis results, and the Synchro output is included in the Appendix.

text.b: Analysis Summary of Brook Road at Site Driveway

page.text: Level of service for minor approach.

operate with acceptable LOS during both the AM and PM peak hours. Under future no-build
and build conditions, all approaches are expected to continue to operate with acceptable LOS

text.i: VCU Virginia Treatment Center for Children – Richmond, Virginia

page.text: Based on the results of the traffic capacity analysis, all of the study intersections currently
operate at an acceptable level-of-service in the AM and PM peak hours, and no off-site
roadway improvements are needed to accommodate the trips generated by the proposed
Virginia Treatment Center for Children (VTCC) – Traffic Impact Analysis
The following is a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) outlining the scope of work and assumptions to be
included in the Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) for the proposed Virginia Treatment Center for Children (VTCC)
on the north side of Sherwood Avenue west of Brook Road. The proposed 32-bed facility is expected to have
up to 120 employees, and is expected to be built-out in 2015. Figure 1 shows an aerial of the site location.
Based on discussion with you, following is our understanding of the TIA requirements:
The following intersections will be analyzed:
 Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard (signalized)
 Brook Road at Existing Hospital Driveways
 Sherwood Avenue at Existing Hospital Driveways
The TIA will include analysis of the following three traffic conditions:
We will use Synchro 8 to perform the traffic capacity analysis.
We conducted AM peak hour (7:00 to 9:00 AM) and PM peak hour (4:00 to 6:00 PM) turning movement counts
during a typical weekday at the following intersections:
 Brook Road at Brookland Park Boulevard
 Brook Road at Existing Hospital Driveways
 Sherwood Avenue at Existing Hospital Driveways
The existing AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 2.
Based on discussion with you, we understand that there are no approved developments in the vicinity of the site
that will have a significant impact on the study intersections.
Following is a summary of the average daily traffic (ADT) volume data published by VDOT for Brook Road in
To be conservative, we will apply an annual growth rate of 3.0% to the peak hour traffic volumes at the study
The new site trips will be distributed to the existing driveways based on the existing traffic patterns. The
 40% to / from the west on Sherwood Avenue
 20% to / from the south on Brook Road
 20% to / from the north on Brook Road
 15% to / from the west on Brookland Park Boulevard
 5% to / from the east on Brookland Park Boulevard
Figure 3 shows the site trip distribution.
Table 1 shows the average weekday daily and peak hour trips for the existing facility based on the Institute of
Edition, and the AM and PM peak hour traffic

text.i: ITE Equation

page.text: In this case, the ITE trip generation equation based on the number of employees matches the actual trip
generation of the site closely. Table 2 shows the ITE trip generation calculations for the proposed facility based
on the number of employees and the number of beds. To be conservative, the trip generation potential of the
new facility will be based on the top line of Table 2.

text.i: ITE Equation
ITE Average Rate
ITE Average Rate

page.text: We will perform the TIA based on the assumptions described in this letter – unless we hear differently from
you. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact me at (804) 217-8560.
Mr. Robert Reardon, Virginia Commonwealth University
Mr. Michael Fievet, Jones Lang LaSalle Americas, Inc.
